OP

i recently moved to NYC to work for a "lucrative salary" (not really, because this place drains you of all your income) and after working here for 4 months i dont know why anyone would willingly live here

>the entire city smells like rotting shit, cigarette buds and dead animals, not a faint smell, an extremely strong odor that you'll eventually just become nose blind to

>homeless people, fucking everywhere, when i left my apartment there were homeless people sleeping in the hallways of my complex, when you go on walk there are homeless people sleeping on the sidewalk with a PILLOW and BLANKET while regular people walk over them like this is just some normal fucking occurrence (and in this shithole it is) never ever have i seen some shit like this even in the worst of cities ive lived in.

>heroin needles, weed bags, cigarette buds & the occasional dildo just scattered across the city sidewalks, your constantly walking over human shit, broken bottles or dime bags

>rats and rodents EVERYWHERE. il never forget the time i bought a pizza from one of the disgusting street vendors and when i sat down at a table one of the rats were circling my feet trying to climb my leg for a bite.

>the "public transport" system is a just permanent housing for the mentally ill, every time i had to ride the subway i was scared for my life because of all the fucking looneys that inhabit the train systems

this is just off the top of my head, but i think the biggest mindfuck of it all is that its EXPENSIVE to live here its gonna cost you not 50k, not 100k, not 200k, to live comfortably by yourself you need 250K yearly in manhattan. 250k, to live among violent homeless people, 250k to constantly have to walk in rotting shit and roadkill. 250k to have your ears blown out by car horns & niggerbabble, 250k to be forced to smell the most putried scents imaginable i dont know why anyone sane would live here, this place is some sort of social experiment, some sort of anonmoly.

Currently expecting to make ~$32.2k (AGI) for 2026 but I am only putting in $400 a month into a traditional 401k.

Also, would I be retarded to take out a 5 year, $10k loan @ 9.5 APR to buy LINK? I plan to stake in the pool and HODL for no less than 5 years, probably much longer. Would the opportunity cost be such that it's better to throw that ~$210 a month into retirement instead? It's literally fun money I cannot use for fun anymore so I dunno what to do with it and I got 35 years left wageslaving.

61872614
>>61872582
I always benchmark the S&P 500, which long-term has a sharpe just short of 1. Depends a lot on what period you look at of course.

Risk-adjusted returns are one way to look at a portfolio, but I also like to look at raw standard deviations and correlations. If an asset class has a decent (relative to S&P 500 always for me) CAGR I consider it. I consider a lot more if the correlation to the S&P 500 is low. This balancing act is why I kinda hate treasuries as a class.

I don't really give a shit about volatility if the CAGR is high and correlations are low of all the holdings. It means a smoother, consistent, strong ride up in all environments (stocks go down but my gold rallies hard af and my cat bonds do nothing). Just how I operate. I rebalance a portfolio of mostly gold, bitcoin, equities, and cat bonds once or twice a year.

61872637
>>61872614
What do you look for correlation-wise when building a portfolio? inverse correlation? a gradient distribution (variety)?

61872644
>>61872593
>I just discovered the Saver's Credit for taxes...
Taxes are so complicated that projections like that require specialized software to min/max. The short answer is you'll get a ~$480 credit on your taxes for the 401k contributions. Works for Roth IRA contributions as well btw, which has a lot of flexibility around taking the money out early. Roth is generally better for low income too, I'd say check with your 401k plan and make sure you're capturing the company match and see if they let you contribute as Roth.

>Also, would I be retarded to take out a 5 year, $10k loan @ 9.5 APR to buy LINK?
Probably not the best idea because it's hard to beat a probable 9% interest rate (aka return) hurdle. I'm ignorant about how LINK works though I only care about Monero and BTC for crypto.

61872698
>>61872637
Mostly inverse correlation to S&P and total historical return of the class.

After that it's risk adjusted return and correlation to other assets in the portfolio. The pic in my OP is kind of looking at that, was some quick DD I was doing with data I pulled to build a correlation matrix. Used a lot of tickers as proxies for classes in a pinch. Not a good time period since it was so short, only 10 years, and 2022 threw a LOT of data off for fixed income because of how fast we increased rates. Here's 26 years of data (I prefer 30 then also looking through regimes back to '71 but the data just isn't there for a lot of these).

I like seeing at LEAST 6% historical CAGR more preferably 8%. Then I want it to have a low (<0.3) or negative correlation to the growth engine (S&P 500). Gold is an oddly great choice for this, but I don't go over 10% overall because of the very flat periods gold has historically.

For each asset class there's the give/take of CAGR vs volatility vs correlation and some asset classes just are better than others objectively. Then there's a handful that when you put them together they just work really well because they all move in different directions but trend strongly up long-term.

OP

I really need to stake my stack. Seeing as the official pool is permanently closed, I'm considering the unthinkable and staking through a third party. How risky is this? I see that the guy behind Linkpool is British like myself, so I could possibly launch litigation if the smart contract ever became compromised + cubes stolen. Early replies (first 3)

61873888
>>61873878

61873939
>>61873878
Its famous for le horserimmer.
Yeah its fine, they fucked us over once. Well technically not me because i got in so early i still made money. i would still consider them trustworthy, they wont steal your linkies

61873943
>>61873878
dont do it man, how often do we have to tell you this

Latest replies (last 30, oldest → newest)

61873966
>>61873878
They've been running smoothly for a long time now and I consider them low risk. If you're a stickler, then yes, the vault manager is secured by a multisig. stake.link fills vault contracts with 15k LINK each and then controls them all with a master contract.
https://etherscan.io/address/0xAc12290b097f6893322F5430627e472131fBC1B5#tokentxns

The vault manager is moderated by the contract owner, which would be a multisig.
https://etherscan.io/address/0x2339ad1a674fb8be412df6cc1c80fb2ba5c3f647#code

In the unlikely event that the multisig is compromised, I'm not sure what the attacker could do. there are some natural limits in place due to the nature of chainlink staking. They wouldn't be able to instantly empty the vaults because the LINK is staked. But they could theoretically call upgradeVaults to do something naughty. If you want to know more then you should talk to them directly, they're pretty responsive.
